bioghist.p: Eugene Ormandy (1899-1985) was a Hungarian-born conductor and violinist. Ormandy came to the US in 1921 and joined the orchestra of the Capitol Theater, becoming its associate music director in 1926. From 1931 to 1936 he became conductor of the Minneapolis Symphony. In 1936 he was invited to become co-conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, sharing the podium with Leopold Stokowski. He was made music director in 1938. During the 44 years of his tenure, the orchestra made many recordings with RCA and with Columbia Records, toured frequently, and broadcast performances on radio and television. Although he retired as conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra at the end of the 1979-1980 season, he continued to appear as conductor laureate and guest conducted all over the US and in Europe.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of 129 reel-to-reel tapes and 30 cassette tapes of performances by the Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Eugene Ormandy and of performances by other orchestras, including the Chicago Symphony, the Cleveland Orchestra, and the New York Philharmonic. The recordings include air checks from WFLN's series of Philadelphia Orchestra transcriptions, demo tapes of novel compositions and of performers. A number of the recordings appear to have been made by the Magnetic Recorder and Reproducer Corp. In addition to the tapes, the collection also includes a commemorative diploma presented to Ormandy by the government of Hungary on the occasion of the 100th anniversary of Zoltan Kodaly's birth.
